text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC., WHEN WE LIVED MOST OF MY SCHOOL BACK AND FORTH.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Would you go to visit more often if there was an invitation? Would you go to visit more often if there was an invitation?

5. The usual way to make money for church or organization—tilts in the 90's.

6. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the plants?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, what drives or dances in homes? Describe our annual dance and parties in the homes when we went to school in Miroonum, but most certainly in the 80's.

8. How many times did you play card games—whist, Old Maid, Authors and Old Maid?

9. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were there in your school district? How many homes were there in your town or village?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? How often did you usually visit relatives?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Or was most visiting done without invitation?

5. What kind of refreshments were usually served at parties? It wasn't easy to send word.

6. Did you ever have parties? If so, what kind of parties were they?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what sort of dances or dances in homes?

8. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not mentioned these on the school questionnaire.

The five years that I (or someone else) taught at [school name] in 1894-95, we held a Christmas celebration in the school house. The building wasn't fitted suitably for dances, etc., although occasionally a Revelling Party would put on a show of some kind.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

In summer we went by buggy, buckboard or waggon. Sometimes a dance was held in the school house, but not too often.

Describe when we were allowed rides out to homes in the country where we were raised. Games would be played.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

At [school name] in 1891, there was a barn dance put on by the students. Someone from the giddies, who called off for the square dances.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls referred to in question 8, 9, and 10 did the entire family attend?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

There would be a shed or stable. Not many parties were in

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Authors, Old Maid,

Buck, Five Hundred, Pitch, Tiddly Winks

Was there card playing for a prize? Not that I remember.

What dances were popular? Square Dances, Waltzes, Cakewalk Step,

Christian Circle, Old Dan Tucker, Polka, Military March

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. If so, was it against the rules of one church that certain named things were not to be done & must members tried to avoid doing.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

We were brought up as Presbyterians & didn't have these rules paid down specifically, although my mother told me that all sinful amusements were just as strict in our church.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree, parades, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.

The five years that I (name) attended the school, we held a Christmas celebration at the building. We used the building for various purposes, such as a church hall, although occasionally a bowling party would be held there.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Croquet was a favorite game for adults, also ball games. In the winter, there were skating parties out to homes in the country where we would go. Games would be played.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it—the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, etc.? If so, how often?)

At what date was the hall built?

Place was fit for dancing. Sometimes there was the square dance.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? (e.g., cradle, bassinet, etc.)

How were horses and cattle provided for? (e.g., stable, barn, etc.)

There would be a shed or coach house for these purposes.

11. What card games were popular?

What dances were popular?

Christian Circle—Old Man Tucker? Polka, military schottische.

Was there card playing for a prize? Not that I remember.

Were there any disagreements between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing assisted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

We were brought up as strict Puritans, and didn't have these socials and dances. Especially in regard to dancing and card playing, when I questioned my mother, she was just as strict in our church.
ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

The Board of Hope for Children & Royal Temples for adults.

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Grain Growers' Club in your community? If so, how many members did it have?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? If so, how many members did it have?

Tell when it was organized. How many women belonged to it?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

The Board of Hope for Children & Royal Temperance for adults.

Give the date and reason for its purpose.

16. Was there a Temperance Club in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

I had the book "On Poverty" but gave it to Mrs. C.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Ed Ranshade was known as the Father of the Temperance Association.

He was the organizer of a Temperance Club in your district.

When was it organized? Before 1914

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

During the first year they helped in any country cause.

Later they changed to doing Red Cross work entirely.

Another time they raised money for the Orange Lodge.

Another time they raised money for the Orange Lodge.
17. Someone warned us that a storm was coming; fires were to be put out, and all were warned to leave for better shelter. I looked around outside for my husband & children. They could be seen all around, some on top of sheds. They didn't make any move to leave, so I made a bee-line myself for home & just got in when heavy hail etc. struck. Others came rushing in drenched & we began cooking. The tent had blown down & general havoc was made at the grounds.
Someone warned us that a storm was coming fires were to be put out; and all were warned to leave for better shelter. I looked around outside for my husband & children. They could be seen all around, some on top of sheds. They didn't make any move it seemed to leave, so I made a bee-line myself for home & just got in when heavy hail etc struck. Others came rushing in drenched & like to go into cooking. The tent had blown down & general havoc was made grounds.
18. Make any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1941, at the time the name of the town changed. If there was first organization, mention what it included (people only, in one relatively small area, or example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands etc.? Yes!

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

1876 a petition at Morning Pointe. He opened reminiscences Nicholas Blood Woman was a prominent speaker. crowds attended to hear him as any good speaker.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumblety-peg, ball, marbles, kite kites, etc.)?

Scroll ball, base ball, touch & run a mile away.

baseball, soccer, tug

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Squat Tag, Avoid the dark, And High Over, skipping rope.

outside

ball etc.

18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1944, give the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, its local purpose(s), its constituency, its membership, its location within the school district, or was centered in the town or village, and something of the organization connected with the church, so they need not be included here.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Have you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them, where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Was well attended. Heard by filled hearing hall. McDonald

1876 a political meeting at Morning Pointe. He could remembe

Poveshull's Blood Union was a phenomenal speaker.

Crowds attended to hear him as very good speaker.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

21. What games did boys play in summer (baseball, ball, marbles, kite kites, etc.)?

Soccer ball, base ball, Touch & run a mile away

base ball, baseball, tug of war, etc.

Squirt jag, Noisy the ducks, And high over, shippping rope

Baseball, soccer, tug

For a time—but that was in the '20s we were privileged to hear many good lectures at the Chautauqua Indian Head.

Rev. Wm. Nicholl an early Presbyterian minister in Moosomin; for a time would give once a year would give a talk or lecture on some subject from the Bible, and whoever remembered most the following year received a prize. Once I was the winner and received a Natural History book, which I made good use of in school work.

Rev. R.E. Knowles when a student missionary in the late '80s, stationed near Moosomin for a time was an eloquent speaker & lecturer. He afterwards wrote several books—one "The Sweet Singers of the Kootenays."

There were others both men & women who helped in the education of our West with their fine lectures.
For a time—but that was in the '20s we were privileged to hear many good lectures at the Chautauqua Indian Head.

Rev. Mr. Nicholas, an early Presbyterian minister in Moosomin, for a time would give once a year would give a talk or lecture on some subject from the Bible, and whoever remembered most the following year received a prize. Once I was the winner and received a Natural History book, which I made good use of in school work.

Rev. R.E. Knowles when a student missionary in the late '80s, stationed near Moosomin for a time was an eloquent speaker & lecturer. He afterwards wrote several books—one "The Sweet Songs of the Hootenays."

There were others both men & women who helped in the education of our West with their fine lectures.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc., etc.? Would you have been able to play on the Big Woods? What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as whist, pinochle, checkers, chess, checkers, etc.? Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

In real early days older people didn't have much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

People were very early and used to bed early.

The daylight gold needed to be saved very good and heads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Got and horseplay.

We never played buffalo bones or arrowheads near us at any time; as children we sometimes made arrowheads out of clay outdoors, and have a grassy yard & buildings.

He has never been in the woods.

Who organized it? I think it was Mr. Johnson.

Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Remember always clearing a long parade going to ground.

Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Raccoon - egg race - pierced the needle, lay of cards, ball games.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Pancakes, cake, fruit, lemonade.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Vassar," or others, checkers or other games?

23. In real early days older people didn't have much time for games, but the children did.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals? Or games in the snow? Describe.

25. Who organized it? I think it was the Senior SS.

26. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Remember always clearing a long parade going to ground.

27. Was it the first parade held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that has been held?

28. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? "Paddle" - "Egg Race" - "Pinched the Needle" - "Tag of war" - ball games.

29. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches, cake, fruit, ice cream, lemonade was a favorite drink.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of these picnics which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

26. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what event was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
Indian Pow Wows at Moosomin in the 80's would take place on the streets usually before a store and remain there until something in the line of food was handed out. The Indians and squaws
Indian pow wows at Moosomin in the 80's would take place on the streets usually before a store and remain there until something in the line of food was handed out. The Indians and squaws

40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 21st or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Olive masses, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, as nearly as you can for many books you bought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

It contained too, a record of our family life, with lots of pictures on it.

Pilgrims Progress - John Bunyan

In May of Homestead

John Yorrmans Talks

A Gaelic Bible.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? To build an extensive collection of books, lend or borrow them, etc.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

One was a Natural History Book given to me by my long-fellow, Cathal O'Connell, from Ireland.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
40. Then did an annual sports day become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st?)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
   hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
   names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
   books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

It contained too, a record of our family Bible, with lots of pictures on it.

Pilgrims Progress—John Bunyan

My Way of Grassmere

John Yorrmans Talks

a Gaelic Bible.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? To what extent were they
   returned to the owner? Give details.

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

One was a "National History Book" given to me by my
young fellow in Cathcart town.

47. Have you had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

Gave these to Mrs. Smith.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
    material?
1898. We had had the study of Hiawatha in school and parents and others in the district besides. The pupils in school became interested and showed their interest by this gift which is in my possession yet.
1898. We had had the study of Hiawatha in school and parents and others in the district besides. The pupils in school became interested and showed their interest by this gift which is in my possession yet.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   The Montreal Leader, John Young, Editor.
   The Northern Messenger.
   The Winnipeg Free Press.

Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you dropped certain titles and others and added others.

52. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Canadian packages of reading matter?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

53. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

54. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   Then was it started?
   In it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    the district?
    The Manitoba Liberal, John Youngell, Editor.
    The Northern Messenger.
    The Winnipeg Free Press.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you subscribed,
    and in what papers and periodicals.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady's Library packages of reading
    matter?
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the meet were you to you most
    useful?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information to your
    study large in the work at Hartington? Explain.
Classes for music teaching. If I remember rightly they were for any who would buy their instruction books. They were high class and a great help to the community. I wish I could remember their names, and had kept their books we had. Moving from place to place, we gave away much it would have been nice to keep.

Later, at Sintaluta, Professors of music from Wolveley & Indian Head would form Choral Society and many took advantage of the training & put on a concert at the end of the term. The women dressed in white, the sopranos wearing red badges the altos blue. I forget what color the men wore.
Classes for music teaching. If I remember rightly they were for anyone who would buy their instruction books. They were high class and a great help to the community. I wish I could remember their names, and had kept their books we had. Moving from place to place, we gave away much it would have been nice to keep.

Later, at Sintaluta, Professor of music from Wolseley & Indian Head would form Choral Society and many took advantage of the training & put on a concert at the end of the term. The women dressed in white, the sopranos wearing red badges the altos blue. I forget what color the men wore.
